thread.title: The Morning Ledger: Trade Spat Affects U.S., Chinese Tech Companies

author: Nina Trentmann
title: The Morning Ledger: Trade Spat Affects U.S., Chinese Tech Companies
text:
0 COMMENTS Sign up for the Morning Ledger, emailed to you each weekday morning. Follow us on Twitter: @CFOJournal. All CFO Journal-produced content can be accessed without a subscription. 
People walk by the ZTE stand at the Mobile World Congress in Barcelona, Spain, Feb. 26, 2018. AFP/Getty Images Good morning. Executives at U.S. and Chinese technology firms are faced by new challenges, as the trade spat between Washington and Beijing affects companies’ deal making, sales and supply chains, write the WSJ’s Yoko Kubota and Dan Strumpf. ZTE Corp. and Qualcomm Inc. are two companies caught in the crosshairs of the dispute.
Qualcomm is confronted by a potential stumbling block for its purchase of NXP Semiconductors NV, as Chinese antitrust regulators on Thursday warned that they have “hard to resolve” concerns about the deal.
The move follows a decision by the U.S. Commerce Department to ban sales of American components to Chinese telecommunications company ZTE, as well as threats from the White House to levy tariffs on $150 billion worth of Chinese goods in response to concerns about the treatment of intellectual property rights.
ZTE is forced to assess whether it must — or even can — replace key components such as semiconductors supplied by Qualcomm and the Android mobile operating system it uses, made by Alphabet Inc.’s Google, write Mr. Strumpf and Newley Purnell. While locked out of the market for networking technology, ZTE has grown its smartphone business, which is now the fourth largest among U.S. consumers.
THE DAY AHEAD 
General Electric Co. , Honeywell International Inc. , Procter & Gamble Co. , State Street Corp. and Schlumberger Ltd. are among the companies slated to report earnings today.
CFO JOURNAL EXCLUSIVE 
British pest control firm Rentokil Initial seeks U.S. targets. Britain’s Rentokil Initial PLC is hunting for takeover targets in the U.S., encouraged by a lower tax rate and strong growth in its core business, Chief Financial Officer Jeremy Townsend said.
The company, which provides pest control, hygiene and workwear services, has allocated £200 to £250 million ($285 million to $356 million) for mergers and acquisitions this year, predominantly for bolt-on deals, said Mr. Townsend. It already has completed 12 such transactions in the first quarter, five of those in the U.S., Mr. Townsend said.
“Half of the world’s pest control [market] is in North America,” Mr. Townsend said Thursday in an interview with CFO Journal. “There are new pests occurring in the U.S. all the time.”
CORPORATE NEWS 
A sign at Uber’s headquarters in San Francisco, Calif., U.S. Zuma Press Uber chooses VMware’s Rowe as top CFO candidate. Uber Technologies Inc. has selected VMware Inc.’s Zane Rowe as the top candidate for the position of chief financial officer, people familiar with the matter told Bloomberg. One of the tasks for the new CFO will be to prepare for what could be the biggest initial public offering of 2019.
Apple struggles to diversify screen suppliers. Apple Inc.’s attempts efforts to line up a second supplier for its smartphone screens — a move to reduce its dependence on Samsung Electronics Co. — have hit a hurdle because LG Display Co. is struggling to make them, according to people familiar with the matter.
Mattel names fourth CEO in as many years. Mattel Inc. Chief Executive Margo Georgiadis is leaving the toy maker after about a year in the job, a surprising shake-up at a company searching for a strategy that can end a four-year sales slump. Former studio executive Ynon Kreiz will succeed Ms. Georgiadis, Mattel said Thursday.
Philip Morris shares suffer biggest daily fall in a decade. Shares of tobacco companies dived after Philip Morris International Inc. said cigarette shipments fell more than expected and sales for its cigarette alternative started to stall in a key market, raising concerns about the state of the industry.
Shire has suitors circling. Drugmaker Shire PLC , one of the few remaining biotech firms with rapidly rising sales, is being pursued by a number of potential buyers, including Japan’s Takeda Pharmaceutical Co. 
Xerox says CEO had authority for Fujifilm deal talks. Xerox Corp. defended its chief executive against accusations from one of its biggest investors Thursday, saying Jeff Jacobson had proper board authority to negotiate a deal with Fujifilm Holdings Inc. 
Home Depot in tech hiring push. Home Depot Inc. is hiring about 1,000 technology employees by the end of this year, the biggest technology-focused expansion in company history and a sign of the growing strategic importance of IT to the business.
Merger not the only option for Renault, Nissan — Ghosn. Carlos Ghosn, chairman and chief executive of the Renault-Nissan-Mitsubishi alliance, said he is open to a merger of Renault and Nissan — something he has rejected for a long time — but added that there may be other alternatives once he eventually retires.
REGULATION 
Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg arrives to testify before a Senate Judiciary and Commerce Committees joint hearing in Washington, D.C., U.S., April 10, 2018. Reuters Audit cleared Facebook’s privacy practices after leak. An auditor reviewing Facebook Inc.’s privacy practices gave the social-media company a clean bill of health in a report to federal authorities last year. This occurred well after Facebook discovered that political consulting firm Cambridge Analytica improperly gained access to millions of users’ personal data.
AT&T CEO rejects antritrust concerns. AT&T Inc. Chief Executive Randall Stephenson Thursday told a judge the U.S. Justice Department’s antitrust claims against his company’s planned purchase of Time Warner Inc. were “absurd” and rejected the government’s arguments that the enlarged company would use its powers to raise prices.
Barclays CEO fined. Barclays PLC Chief Executive Jes Staley will keep his job after British regulators concluded his attempts to unmask a whistleblower didn’t represent a “lack of integrity” and instead chose to slap the U.S. executive with a fine.
Wells Fargo close to settlement. Wells Fargo & Co. is close to settling claims by federal regulators related to its risk management, involving a fine of as much as $1 billion, people familiar with the matter said.
Rusal searches for new home for its aluminum as sanctions bite. Aluminum from United Co. Rusal PLC , the recently sanctioned Russian miner, is looking for a new home after the London Metal Exchange banned deliveries of Rusal metal to its warehouses.
China seeks to establish the right prices for tech listings lured home. China’s government wants Alibaba Group Holding Ltd. and other Chinese tech giants listed abroad to trade on the nation’s stock markets. Regulators are trying to figure out how to make sure that those companies’ shares don’t fall too low or soar too high.
Lease accounting standard forecast to hit U.S. firms. More than three-quarters of the top 100 U.S. companies with the biggest lease obligations expect to see a material impact on their balance sheet from the new lease accounting standard, reports Accounting Today.
ECONOMY 
Germany’s Minister of Finance Olaf Scholz is seen in Washington, April 19, 2018. EPA German finance minister criticizes protectionist push. Germany’s new finance minister, Olaf Scholz, criticized a return toward protectionism and nationalism during a visit to Washington, as European Union leaders try to avoid trade tariffs announced by the Trump administration.
U.S. economic indicator rose in March. An economic index that measures U.S. business trends continued to rise in March. The Conference Board Leading Economic Index increased 0.3% to 109, following rises in January and February.
U.S. jobless claims keep falling. The number of Americans claiming new unemployment benefits fell last week for the third time in four weeks, signaling continued strength in the labor market.
Japan’s car exports risk trade fight with Trump administration. Japanese auto makers exported nearly 10% more cars to the U.S. in the first three months of this year compared with the same period a year earlier, according to trade figures released this week in Tokyo. President Trump wants the country to commit to a bilateral deal to reduce its trade surplus with the U.S.
CFO MOVES 
Bloomsbury Publishing PLC , a British publishing house, appointed Penny Scott-Bayfield as chief financial officer, effective July 16, 2018. Ms. Scott-Bayfield succeeds Wendy Pallot who will step down from her role on July 18, 2018. Ms. Scott-Bayfield is currently finance director at Conde Nast Inc.’s U.K. business. Prior to joining Conde Nast, she held senior finance roles at Sky PLC and Lastminute.com PLC. Compensation details were not immediately available.
Debenhams PLC , a British department-store operator, said its current CFO Matt Smith will leave the group to take up the role of finance director at competitor Selfridges & Co. Debenhams has commenced the search for a successor. Mr. Smith has been Debenhams CFO since Jan. 2015.
THE WEEKEND READER 
Every weekend we select a handful of in-depth articles we think are worth a bit of your time, either because they peel back the layers on a compelling business story, or somehow make us look at business in a different light. 
How Palantir gets to know everything about you. Palantir Technologies Inc.’s engineers and products don’t do any spying themselves; they’re more like a spy’s brain. The software combs through disparate data sources and searches for connections that human analysts might miss. It then presents the linkages in colorful, easy-to-interpret graphics that look like spider webs, reports Bloomberg Businessweek.
What to think of before hiring a friend. You can be a friend and a boss, assuming that you have the right combination of patience and candor before and during the hiring process, argues Harvard Business Review.
How to cram in more media. Unread books. Unheard music albums. Unwatched films and television series, plus a heap of audiobooks: The amount of media content you think you cannot miss can be overwhelming. The Financial Times explains how to get more media into your day.
